content: The Act titled "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property under section 25E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007 introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. The credit allows for 25% of the expenditures, up to a maximum of $5,000 per taxable year, for specific property improvements to mitigate hurricane and tornado damage. The Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007 offers a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. The credit covers 25% of the expenditures, up to $5,000 per year, for specific property improvements to prevent damage. This includes protecting openings from windborne debris and exterior doors and garages in qualified dwelling units located in specified states with assessed values below $1,000,000. The Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007 provides a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. Expenditures must be completed in a manner deemed adequate by a State-certified inspector, including labor and inspection costs. The Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007 offers a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified property expenditures. Subsection (c) affects the taxpayer's mitigation expenses for hurricanes and tornadoes in the taxable year. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections in the tax code. The Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007 introduces a new tax credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2007. The Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007 introduces a tax credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. The credit is 25% of the expenditures, not exceeding $5,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include improving roof strength, creating water barriers, enhancing roof durability, bracing walls, reinforcing roof connections, and protecting openings from debris. The tax credit introduced by the Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007 is for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. The credit is 25% of the expenditures, up to $5,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include improving roof strength, creating water barriers, enhancing roof durability, bracing walls, reinforcing roof connections, and protecting openings from debris. A qualified place of business must be assessed at a value less than $5,000,000 in a qualified State. The tax credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures under the Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007 is subject to certain limitations. Expenditures must be approved by a State-certified inspector, and labor and inspection costs are also considered in determining the qualified expenditures. The tax credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures is subject to limitations and must be approved by a State-certified inspector. Labor and inspection costs are also considered in determining the qualified expenditures. Section 38(b) of the Code is amended to include the hurricane and tornado mitigation credit under section 45O(a). The amendments made by this section regarding the hurricane and tornado mitigation credit will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
